results.title: In the bush [Greek Version]
results.brief_description: This film provides a view of some unique Australian birds and animals. In particular, the platypus, echidna, kangaroo and koala in natural surroundings. Commentary in Greek language only - no subtitles. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: In the beginning. Part I
results.brief_description: Sir Kenneth Clark discusses Egypt and the Nile valley. Shows him travelling there and pointing out the ways isn which Egypt flourished as an early civilisation. Presents the art and architecture of that early time. Part I of a two part series. Suitable for upper secondary level. NB: Part II (reel 2) is missing

results.title: In the beginning
results.brief_description: An educational film taking as its starting point “All animals come from the egg”. Depicts with photography and diagrams, ovulation, fertilisation and early cell division of a rabbit embryo. Having depicted a number of scenes of dissection/vivisection, the film concludes with some footage of live animals and a human baby.

results.title: In spite of wishing and wanting
results.creator_credit: Ultima Vez, Quasi Modo, Bart Van Langendonck and Wim Vandekeybus
results.brief_description: Ultima Vez is a dance company formed by director, choreographer, actor and photographer Wim Vandekeybus in 1985. His style is high adrenaline with genuine sense of jeopardy and he draws his dance vocabulary from everyday movement. In creating this piece, Vandekeybus worked in close collaboration with composer David Byrne and with an all-male company. Poetic and passionate, the performance is a powerful and moving mix of movement, music, symbol, words and silence that explores the different tensions, responses, emotions and energy generated by the single-sex cast. This screen adaption of ‘In Spite of Wishing and Wanting’ based on the 1999 dance performance of the same name was shot in the atmospheric surroundings of a racetrack and at the beautiful ballroom-concert hall ‘Vooruit Arts Center’ in Ghent, Belgium. For further information go to http://www.ultimavez.com/

results.title: In song and dance
results.creator_credit: Waratah Film Productions, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Joy Cavill and Lee Robinson
results.brief_description: The preparations and some scenes of the 1964 Northern Territory Eisteddfod held at Darwin. Local townspeople are joined by cattlemen and aborigines from far out stations, and get together to produce an eisteddfod unlike any other - with items of all kinds, from classical ballet to Aboriginal corroborees.

results.title: In signal honour: 1865-1965, 100 years of telecommunications
results.brief_description: Produced to celebrate the centenary (1865-1965) of the International Telecommunications Union, this film traces the development of telecommunications during the last hundred years, showing the emergence and impact of telephone, radio, television and apace communications. Highlights include international television transmissions.

results.title: In sickness and in health: women and the health care system
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group, John Moore and Carole Sklan
results.brief_description: Women are the most frequent users of the health care system, but have little say in the way it is run. This program outlines how women can deal with and what they need from the health care system. Includes interviews with sociologists, nurse educators, doctors and patients and is designed to awaken consumer and practitioner awareness of women’s rights in health care.

results.title: In shifting sands: the truth about UNSCOM and the disarming of Iraq
results.creator_credit: Five Rivers Productions, Alex Cohn and Scott Ritter
results.brief_description: Former United Nations weapons inspector Scott Ritter has compiled this series of interviews and footage into an interesting account of events leading up to the invasion of Iraq. The weapons inspectors were sent in on a supposedly non-political mission, their knowledge base being about weapons. Frustration with Iraqi officials denying them access to sites is shown and general dissatisfaction in the pressure brought to bear by politicians who were after a desired outcome. No definitive answers are given but the film provides some insight to the trying process the inspectors were put through. Please note that due to the nature of the original source material, the footage of “In shifting sands” is of a variable standard.
